articles.headline: Meta May Allow Instagram and Facebook Users in Europe to Pay to Avoid Ads
articles.snippet: The subscription plan is a response to European Union policies and court rulings to restrict Meta’s data-collection practices.
articles.abstract: The subscription plan is a response to European Union policies and court rulings to restrict Meta’s data-collection practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Meta is considering paid versions of Facebook and Instagram that would have no advertising for users in the European Union, three people with knowledge of the company’s plans said, a response to regulatory scrutiny and a sign that how people experience technology in the United States and Europe may diverge because of government policy.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: A Brutal Path Forward, Village by Village
articles.snippet: As Ukraine pushes slowly forward in its counteroffensive, it’s relying heavily on the effort of hundreds of small-scale assault groups, each tasked with attacking a single trench, tree line or house.
articles.abstract: As Ukraine pushes slowly forward in its counteroffensive, it’s relying heavily on the effort of hundreds of small-scale assault groups, each tasked with attacking a single trench, tree line or house.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mission for the Ukrainian unit was to take a single house, in a village that is only a speck on the map but was serving as a stronghold for Russian soldiers.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Why Did a Drug Gang Kill 43 Students? Text Messages Hold Clues.
articles.snippet: The Mexican police, military officers and others secretly colluded with a cartel that kidnapped 43 students, a case unsolved after nearly a decade. Wiretaps show just how much the authorities helped the cartel behind the mass abduction, and what l...
articles.abstract: The Mexican police, military officers and others secretly colluded with a cartel that kidnapped 43 students, a case unsolved after nearly a decade. Wiretaps show just how much the authorities helped the cartel behind the mass abduction, and what led to it.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is perhaps Mexico’s most notorious cold case — 43 college students shot at by the police, forced into patrol cars, handed over to a drug cartel and never seen again.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Taxes, Drugs and … TikTok?
articles.snippet: How one of Montana’s top elected officials made banning the app a top priority, putting the state at the center of a geopolitical storm.
articles.abstract: How one of Montana’s top elected officials made banning the app a top priority, putting the state at the center of a geopolitical storm.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent summer day, Austin Knudsen, Montana’s attorney general, drove his red Buick from Helena, the state’s capital, to Boulder, a tiny town about a half-hour away whose main claim to fame is that it’s home to the state’s highway patrol. The road was quiet, flanked by the sort of sprawling pastures and expansive landscapes that give Montana its nickname of Big Sky Country.

articles.headline: When Financial Independence Isn’t Always the Goal
articles.snippet: Many Iranian Americans say their families place a high premium on education — sometimes at the expense of early financial independence — potentially complicating their financial futures.
articles.abstract: Many Iranian Americans say their families place a high premium on education — sometimes at the expense of early financial independence — potentially complicating their financial futures.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1996, when I was 16, some of my friends found jobs at our local mall in Jacksonville, Fla. We all came from upper-middle-class families, so working was about building character and earning spending money, not because of financial necessity.

articles.headline: Officials in South Africa Knew About Problems at a ‘Bad Building,’ but Did Nothing
articles.snippet: An extensive paper trail reveals that the authorities in Johannesburg were warned repeatedly about the dangers in the derelict building where 76 people died in a fire this week.
articles.abstract: An extensive paper trail reveals that the authorities in Johannesburg were warned repeatedly about the dangers in the derelict building where 76 people died in a fire this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one was in the dark about what was happening at 80 Albert Street.
articles.byline: By John Eligon, Lynsey Chutel and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Biden Team Isn’t Waiting for Impeachment to Go on the Offensive
articles.snippet: The White House has enlisted two dozen lawyers, legislative liaisons and others to craft strategies in the face of Republican threats to charge the president with high crimes and misdemeanors.
articles.abstract: The White House has enlisted two dozen lawyers, legislative liaisons and others to craft strategies in the face of Republican threats to charge the president with high crimes and misdemeanors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just before 8 p.m. on Thursday, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene posted a video of herself at a town hall in her Georgia district declaring that she “will not vote to fund the government” unless the House holds a vote to open an impeachment inquiry against President Biden.

articles.headline: China to Its People: Spies Are Everywhere, Help Us Catch Them
articles.snippet: As Beijing tries to enlist the “whole of society” to guard against foreign enemies, the line between vigilance and paranoia fades.
articles.abstract: As Beijing tries to enlist the “whole of society” to guard against foreign enemies, the line between vigilance and paranoia fades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beijing sees forces bent on weakening it everywhere: embedded in multinational companies, infiltrating social media, circling naïve students. And it wants its people to see them, too.

articles.headline: Auto Strike Looms, Threatening to Shut Detroit’s Big 3
articles.snippet: With their contract expiring Sept. 14, the United Auto Workers and the companies are far apart in talks. A walkout could take a big economic toll.
articles.abstract: With their contract expiring Sept. 14, the United Auto Workers and the companies are far apart in talks. A walkout could take a big economic toll.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Auto Workers union and the three Detroit automakers have less than two weeks to negotiate a new labor contract, and a strike of some sort seems increasingly likely.

articles.headline: How a New City Council Map of L.A. Turned Into a Political Brawl
articles.snippet: Blatant political gerrymandering occurs in cities across the country, many of them run by Democrats. In Los Angeles, a scandal over a racist recording was only the tip of the iceberg.
articles.abstract: Blatant political gerrymandering occurs in cities across the country, many of them run by Democrats. In Los Angeles, a scandal over a racist recording was only the tip of the iceberg.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nithya Raman turned into a political celebrity almost overnight when she emerged as the face of a rising progressive vanguard to campaign for the Los Angeles City Council in 2020.
articles.byline: By Jill Cowan, Serge F. Kovaleski and Leanne Abraham

articles.headline: The Never-Ending Nightmare of Ukraine’s Dam Disaster
articles.snippet: Environmentally, economically and in terms of pure human suffering, the destruction of the Kakhovka dam unleashed untold damage. Months later, many communities are still reeling.
articles.abstract: Environmentally, economically and in terms of pure human suffering, the destruction of the Kakhovka dam unleashed untold damage. Months later, many communities are still reeling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sunset along the Kakhovka Reservoir in central Ukraine, especially in summer, used to be gorgeous: kids played in the shallow water near the shore, men fished and young couples walked under the pine trees as the last traces of sunlight reflected off the water.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly

articles.headline: Amid Rain and Mud, Climactic ‘Burn’ Is Delayed at Burning Man Fest
articles.snippet: Officials urged campers to conserve food and water on Sunday, as the police investigated one death. The annual burning of a manlike figure was postponed.
articles.abstract: Officials urged campers to conserve food and water on Sunday, as the police investigated one death. The annual burning of a manlike figure was postponed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The torrential rains that turned roads and grounds into muck and left thousands of people stranded at the Burning Man festival also put off the climax of the carefree celebration of art, music and counterculture: The annual burning of a manlike figure did not happen on Sunday night as had been planned.
articles.byline: By Finn-Olaf Jones, Anna Betts and Amanda Holpuch

articles.headline: Zelensky Replaces Defense Minister, Citing Need for ‘New Approaches’
articles.snippet: The fate of the defense minister, Oleksii Reznikov, had been the subject of increasing speculation in Ukraine. It was the biggest shake-up in Ukraine’s government since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
articles.abstract: The fate of the defense minister, Oleksii Reznikov, had been the subject of increasing speculation in Ukraine. It was the biggest shake-up in Ukraine’s government since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Sunday that he was replacing his minister of defense, the biggest shake-up in the leadership of Ukraine’s war effort since Russia’s full-scale invasion began, citing the need for “new approaches” after more than 18 months of conflict.

articles.headline: China’s Biggest Homebuilder Reels as Economy Slows
articles.snippet: Once considered a survivor of China’s real estate turmoil, Country Garden is now at the center of the crisis and threatens the broader economy.
articles.abstract: Once considered a survivor of China’s real estate turmoil, Country Garden is now at the center of the crisis and threatens the broader economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Country Garden, the biggest developer in China’s increasingly troubled real estate sector, published its annual report in April, the cover design exuded hope: a phoenix spreading its wings.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

articles.headline: E.U. Official From Sweden Imprisoned in Iran for Over 500 Days
articles.snippet: The case of Johan Floderus, kept under wraps for more than a year, has become part of Iran’s “hostage diplomacy” as Tehran seeks concessions from the West.
articles.abstract: The case of Johan Floderus, kept under wraps for more than a year, has become part of Iran’s “hostage diplomacy” as Tehran seeks concessions from the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Swedish citizen working for the European Union diplomatic corps has been imprisoned in Iran for more than 500 days, making him an important bargaining chip for Tehran as it tries to wring concessions from the West.

articles.headline: A Conservative Push to Save Ken Paxton
articles.snippet: The effort to help the Texas attorney general, whose impeachment trial starts Tuesday, is part of an ongoing struggle over the Republican Party’s future.
articles.abstract: The effort to help the Texas attorney general, whose impeachment trial starts Tuesday, is part of an ongoing struggle over the Republican Party’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: With television ads and text messages, direct mail and billboards, supporters of the embattled Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, have embarked on an escalating campaign of political pressure, backed by hard-right billionaires, aimed at trying to sway the outcome of Mr. Paxton’s upcoming impeachment trial.

articles.headline: Faced With Evolving Threats, U.S. Navy Struggles to Change
articles.snippet: A new generation of cheaper and more flexible vessels could be vital in any conflict with China, but the Navy remains lashed to big shipbuilding programs driven by tradition, political influence and jobs.
articles.abstract: A new generation of cheaper and more flexible vessels could be vital in any conflict with China, but the Navy remains lashed to big shipbuilding programs driven by tradition, political influence and jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: A symphony of sorts echoed through the sprawling shipyard on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi — banging, hissing, beeping, horns, bells and whistles — as more than 7,000 workers hustled to fill orders fueled by the largest shipbuilding budget in the Navy’s history.

articles.headline: When It Comes to China, Pope Francis Keeps Criticism in Check
articles.snippet: Francis called relations with Beijing “very respectful,” though few clergy or Catholics from China went to see him during a visit to Mongolia, seemingly fearing reprisals.
articles.abstract: Francis called relations with Beijing “very respectful,” though few clergy or Catholics from China went to see him during a visit to Mongolia, seemingly fearing reprisals.
articles.lead_paragraph: The small group of Chinese Catholics who crossed the border to see Pope Francis covered their faces for fear of reprisal. Church officials blamed the Communist government for preventing mainland China’s bishops from coming to see the pope. And diplomats said that China had watched the pope’s activities closely, and warily.
